thread.title: Google teams up with Kaggle to host $100,000 video classification challenge
thread.title_full: Google teams up with Kaggle to host $100,000 video classification challenge

author: Frederic Lardinois
title: Google teams up with Kaggle to host $100,000 video classification challenge
text:
Google teams up with Kaggle to host $100,000 video classification challenge Posted Reddit tweaks and renames public front page 
Google and Kaggle today announced a new machine learning challenge that asks developers to find the best way to automatically tag videos. 
The challenge, which comes with a $30,000 prize for the first-place finisher (and $25,000, $20,000, $15,000, and $10,000 for the next four teams), asks developers to classify and tag videos from Google’s updated YouTube-8M V2 dataset . This dataset features a total of 7 million YouTube videos that add up to 450,000 hours of video. YouTube-8M already includes labels, too, and developers can use this as their training data. The challenge then is to tag 700,000 previously unseen videos. 
The company is launching this new challenge on the same day of TensorFlow’s 1.0 release and that’s probably no coincidence. Still, Google doesn’t restrict developers to using its own machine learning framework. The can use other frameworks, too. Given that the full frame-level data set is 1.71 TB large, though, and lives on Google’s Cloud Platform, chances are most developers will want to use Google’s own services to train their models (and they can get a few extra free credits to use the Cloud Platform, too, once they run out of their free allotment). 
Just last week, Google also launched the YouTube-BoundingBoxes dataset . As the name implies, this dataset consists of bounding boxes (for a total of 5 million videos) that track objects across frames. This isn’t something the developers will use in this new challenge, but it clearly shows Google’s interest in video classification. YouTube, after all, keeps growing and probably sees more searches than most of Google’s search engine competitors. 0
